content: a revision to run the connecting thread between each knot along the ws of the fabric rather than the rs an explanation of how to work the revised knots for these socks follows the link the palestrina knots are best added before closing the toes the embroidery does not add bulk cuff set up to provisionally cast on 64 72 80 stitches using a waste yarn crochet a chain of 5-6 more stitches than needed using mc insert gn into back of crochet chain to pull up a loop to mount on the needle repeat until required number of stitches are cast on taking care not to twist join in the round place bor marker cuff lining set-up knit 16 rounds purl 1 round this purl round is referred to as the turn ridge sl1 k to bor pro tip the slip_stitch works to neaten the jog at the cuff fold line in circular knitting garter drop stitch cuff round 1 k1 reverse yo repeat to end round 2 p1 drop reverse yo repeat to end round 3 knit round 4 purl round 5 knit round 6 purl repeat rounds 1-6 repeat rounds 1-2 remove the crocheted chain cast on yarn while mounting each live stitch on a set of spare needles in preparation for joining the cuff lining to the cuff facing close the hem with ws s facing together fold the cuff along the turn ridge position needles so the garter cuff is in front the lining behind knit the first stitch on the front needle together with the first stitch on the needle behind knit the next stitch on the front needle together with the next stitch on the needle behind continue as set until 64 72 80 cuff stitches are worked bor pro tip take care not to work too tightly so the join retains same stretch as the cuff © mary pat mcgurk 2023 v 1 5 2 decorative welts 1 continuing with the mc begin welt set up small m1 k32 m1 k32 do not cut mc 66 stitches on needles medium knit as set do not cut mc 72 stitches on needles large ssk k38 ssk k38 do not cut mc 78 stitches on needles 2 creating the welt fabric s m l sizes are worked the same rounds 1-2 with cc1 k5 sl1 wyib continuing to bor rounds 3-10 knit cut cc1 leaving length to weave in in preparation for step 3 below take time to read both the ws and rs of the stitches in rounds 1-10 just completed to better understand the mechanics behind the instructions to follow in step #3 below looking downward at the ws of the welt fabric 10 row below one should be able to see a single line of mc purl bumps that lie just above the first round of cc1 that were worked in round 1 observe the rs of the fabric there s an mc v the slipped stitch every 6th stitch column
